docs.snippet: This week's podcast includes Claire Cain Miller on the updated Google TV software and Nick Wingfield on user complaints about the battery life of the iPhone 4S....
docs.lead_paragraph: Google TV, Google's set-top box software for melding the Internet with the television, was not a huge success when it arrived last year. But while the hardware is staying the same for now, Google announced a software update for Google TV last week with a new user interface, better search tools and new objectives. Claire Cain Miller, a technology reporter in the San Francisco bureau of The New York Times, drops in to explain Google's latest angle for getting into the living room.

headline.main: Tech Talk Podcast: Google TV Redux

docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO - Acknowledging that some searches were giving people stale results, Google revised its methods on Thursday to make the answers timelier. It is one of the biggest tweaks to Google's search algorithm, affecting about 35 percent of all searches.

docs.snippet: SAN FRANCISCO - Acknowledging that some searches were giving people stale results, Google revised its methods on Thursday to make the answers timelier. It is one of the biggest tweaks to Google's search algorithm, affecting about 35 percent of all...
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO - Acknowledging that some searches were giving people stale results, Google revised its methods on Thursday to make the answers timelier. It is one of the biggest tweaks to Google's search algorithm, affecting about 35 percent of all searches. The new algorithm is a recognition that Google, whose dominance depends on providing the most useful results, is being increasingly challenged by services like Twitter and Facebook, which have trained people to expect constant updates with seconds-old news.

headline.main: Google Tries To Improve Timeliness Of Searches

docs.abstract: Google, acknowledging that some searches are giving people stale results, revises its methods to make the answers timelier; change is one of the biggest tweaks ever made to Google's search algorithm, affecting about 35 percent of all searches. Photo (M)i

docs.lead_paragraph: Google is opening its social network, Google+, to companies, organizations and brands. With the move, it hopes to create novel kinds of relationships between people and products, while making inroads against Facebook's own popular corporate pages, partly by using Google search to promote pages.

docs.snippet: Airlines, insurance companies, hospitals and many other organizations are trying to figure out how to corral all their data and turn it into something useful.      Kaggle, a start-up, has figured out a way to connect these companies with the mathe...
docs.lead_paragraph: Airlines, insurance companies, hospitals and many other organizations are trying to figure out how to corral all their data and turn it into something useful. Kaggle, a start-up, has figured out a way to connect these companies with the mathematicians and scientists who crunch numbers for a living or a hobby. On Thursday, it announced it had raised $11 million from investors including Khosla Ventures, Index Ventures and Hal Varian, Google's chief economist.

headline.main: Crunching Data, and Winning Cash

docs.snippet: There are a lot of Google+ haters out there, predicting its ultimate demise. But Google+ isn't going anywhere, and that's not just because Google hopes to build a social network that competes with Facebook, Twitter and others. It's because Google+...
docs.lead_paragraph: There sure are a lot of Google+ haters out there.

headline.main: Google+ Isn't Going Away

docs.abstract: There are a lot of Google+ haters out there, predicting its ultimate demise. But Google+ isn't going anywhere, and that's not just because Google hopes to build a social network that competes with Facebook, Twitter and others. It's because Google+ is a social layer that has always been intended to sit on top of the company's flagship product: search.

docs.snippet: Although Google has long thrived by encouraging upstart projects within the larger company -- one of which developed Gmail -- its new chief executive, Larry Page, is pulling back on this strategy. Since taking over in April, he has killed off more...

headline.main: In a Quest for Focus, Google Purges Small Projects

docs.abstract: Although Google has long thrived by encouraging upstart projects within the larger company -- one of which developed Gmail -- its new chief executive, Larry Page, is pulling back on this strategy. Since taking over in April, he has killed off more than 25 projects he deemed unworthy so that employees could focus on the bigger products.

docs.snippet: Monday, October 24, 9:36 a.m.: As I explained in my last post, I recently found myself with a surprising new problem: all the work we can handle. Because our backlog of orders is as high as I want it to be, I decided to take the opportunity to run...
docs.lead_paragraph: Monday, October 24, 9:36 a.m.: As I explained in my last post, I recently found myself with a surprising new problem: all the work we can handle. Because our backlog of orders is as high as I want it to be, I decided to take the opportunity to run an experiment: What would happen if I stopped running Google AdWords? I have been spending $500 per day on sponsored search, and I believe the results have been well worth the money: $1.8 million in sales as of this morning. But I also believe this is a rare opportunity to see whether AdWords is doing the heavy lifting in our marketing or whether our search engine optimization efforts are yielding results as well.

headline.main: Turning Off AdWords

docs.snippet: A story that is sure to be at the center of the tech conversation today is "Google’s Lab of Wildest Dreams,” a look by Claire Cain Miller and Nick Bilton of The New York Times at Google X, the top-secret lab where Google is working on a list o...

headline.main: Daily Report: Google's Secret Projects

docs.abstract:
A story that is sure to be at the center of the tech conversation today is "Google’s Lab of Wildest Dreams,” a look by Claire Cain Miller and Nick Bilton of The New York Times at Google X, the top-secret lab where Google is working on a list of 100 shoot-for-the-stars ideas — from robots to space elevators (in theory, rocketless travel to outer space along a cable attached to Earth) to ways to connect the Internet to ordinary household items like coffee cups and refrigerators.

The lab is the brainchild of Sergey Brin and Larry Page, Google’s co-founders, as well as other Google executives. It is so secret that most Google employees don’t even know about it. And although logistics for the lab are at the Google campus in Mountain View, Calif., the work with robots is being done at a undisclosed location, somewhere in the Bay Area.

Most of the ideas on the list are conceptual at this point (we’re unlikely to see a space elevator anytime soon), but two people briefed on the project said one product would be released by the end of the year, although they would not say what it was.

“They’re pretty far out in front right now,” Rodney Brooks, a professor emeritus at M.I.T.’s computer science and artificial intelligence lab and founder of Heartland Robotics, says in the story. “But Google’s not an ordinary company, so almost nothing applies.”

Read some of the discussion of the article here:

ReadWriteWeb: So This is Openness, Google X, and What Have You Done? PCMag: Google X: A Secret Lab for Future Products Revealed

And tell Bits what you would like to see the lab focus on.

docs.abstract: Google X is a secret lab at an undisclosed location in the Bay Area, where Google is working on a list of 100 ideas for products yet to be built -- many of them the stuff of science fiction. The projects are still in the conceptual stage. But the lab -- which is so secret that most Google employees don't even know about it -- is a glimpse at how Google imagines the future.

headline.seo: At Google X, a Top-Secret Lab Dreaming Up the Future
headline.main: Google’s Lab of Wildest Dreams

docs.abstract: Google operates a clandestine laboratory called Google X in which engineers and robotics experts are tackling a list of 100 shoot-for-the-stars ideas; lab reflects the company's ambition to be known for ground-breaking research and development; it also underlines the secretive nature of the company as many Google employees do not even know the lab exists.

docs.snippet: Apple is reaching into Google's Wallet.     This week Apple introduced a new feature for the iPhone in its Apple Store app. The feature, called EasyPay, allows people to take a picture of the bar code of a product with the phone's camera and then ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Apple is reaching into Google's Wallet. This week Apple introduced a new feature for the iPhone in its Apple Store app. The feature, called EasyPay, allows people to take a picture of the bar code of a product with the phone's camera and then buy the product on the spot, using their iTunes account.

headline.main: Paying by iPhone At Apple Stores

docs.abstract: Bits blog; Apple introduces iPhone feature EasyPay, which allows shoppers to buy products inside its Apple Stores. Photo (M)4

docs.snippet: Netflix on Tuesday launched a revamped Netflix app for Android tablets before releasing the same new software for the iPad. The move isn't a great sign for Apple, which benefits from the abundance of apps available for its devices. In this case, t...
docs.lead_paragraph: The bounty of apps for iPad and iPhone are one of the cornerstones of Apple's strategy for promoting the devices. It isn't a great sign for the company then, when an important developer says it's going to do a superior app first for Google's rival Android operating system.

headline.main: Netflix Goes Android First, but Barely

docs.abstract: Netflix on Tuesday launched a revamped Netflix app for Android tablets before releasing the same new software for the iPad. The move isn't a great sign for Apple, which benefits from the abundance of apps available for its devices. In this case, the Android Netflix app won't have much of a head start on the new iPad app.

docs.snippet: A tussle between the writer Salman Rushdie and Facebook points to one of the trickiest notions about life in the digital age: Are you who you say you are online? Whose business is it - and why? Major Internet companies like Google, Facebook and Tw...

headline.main: Rushdie Runs Afoul of Web's Real-Name Police

docs.abstract: A tussle between the writer Salman Rushdie and Facebook points to one of the trickiest notions about life in the digital age: Are you who you say you are online? Whose business is it - and why? Major Internet companies like Google, Facebook and Twitter have a valuable stake in the online debate over names and pseudonyms. And in some cases they have vastly different corporate philosophies on the issue that signal their own ambitions.

headline.main: Rushdie Runs Afoul of Web’s Real-Name Police
headline.print_headline: Naming Names: Rushdie Wins Facebook Fight

docs.abstract: Salman Rushdie’s victory in a fight over which name he is allowed to use on his Facebook account highlights an increasingly vital debate over how people represent themselves on the Web; the argument over pseudonyms, known online as the 'nym wars,' goes to the heart of how the Internet might be organized in the future; major Internet companies like Google, Facebook and Twitter have a valuable stake in this debate, and in some cases, vastly different corporate philosophies on the issue that signal their future directions and ambitions.

docs.snippet: Reporters are arrested in Zuccotti Park, CBS presents its new "Early Show" lineup and Google is expected to announce its own online music-download store....
docs.lead_paragraph: The day after the nighttime raid that cleared protesters from Zuccotti Park, the New York Police Department was criticized by local politicians and news organizations for its treatment of reporters and the restrictions it placed on how they do their work. The Associated Press reported that at least half a dozen reporters were arrested in and around the park, home of the Occupy Wall Street movement, including a reporter and photographer from the agency. Michael Oreskes, senior managing editor for The A.P., said: "Journalists should not be restricted from access to news events or detained for attempting to do their jobs. We were unhappy that two of our staff members were swept up in the police operation, but we appreciate the N.Y.P.D.'s decision to release them."

headline.main: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 16

docs.abstract: Reporters are arrested in Zuccotti Park, CBS presents its new "Early Show" lineup and Google is expected to announce its own online music-download store.

headline.main: Google Allows Wi-Fi Owners to Opt Out of Database
headline.print_headline: Google Agrees to Allow Owners of Wi-Fi Routers to Opt Out of Database

docs.abstract: Google, under pressure from regulators in the Netherlands, agrees to give people around the world the option of keeping the names and locations of their home or business Wi-Fi routers out of a company database used to help pinpoint locations of mobile devices; if many people opt out of the registry, Google's ability to offer location-based services could be compromised.

byline.contributor: Claire Cain Miller contributed reporting from San Francisco.

docs.snippet: 8:26 p.m. | Updated Looking to extend its reach as a hub for entertainment and social networking, Google introduced a set of music features on Wednesday, including a download store to compete with iTunes.     The service, Google Music, will sell i...
docs.lead_paragraph: 8:26 p.m. | Updated Looking to extend its reach as a hub for entertainment and social networking, Google introduced a set of music features on Wednesday, including a download store to compete with iTunes. The service, Google Music, will sell individual tracks and full albums, letting customers store the songs on servers, on so-called cloud accounts. And through an integration with Google's nascent social network, Google+, the company will also let customers share music by offering friends one free listen to any bought track.

headline.main: Music Service From Google Will Sell and Store Songs

docs.abstract: Google introduces its service Google Music, which includes a download store to compete with iTunes. (M)0

docs.snippet: Because Google Apps performs many of the same functions as Office, but through a Web browser instead of local software, it is cheaper to own and operate than Microsoft’s desktop software, he said. It has been more than 4 1/2 years since Google b...

headline.main: Daily Report: Google Keeps Pushing at Microsoft's Windows

docs.abstract:
Because Google Apps performs many of the same functions as Office, but through a Web browser instead of local software, it is cheaper to own and operate than Microsoft’s desktop software, he said.

It has been more than 4 1/2 years since Google began its cloud computing challenge to Microsoft’s lucrative Office division, maker of Microsoft Word and PowerPoint. It has had some wins, reports Quentin Hardy in an article on Google Apps in Monday’s New York Times. But the question remains how much of a dent Google is making in Microsoft’s business.

Microsoft says Google’s efforts are hardly noticeable. But Google executives say that more and bigger companies are signing up for the cloud service. Possibly more important to Google is the way that Apps helps Google build social networks inside business. If successful, it would be a threat to Microsoft’s biggest division and would create another inroad in its struggle with Facebook to dominate users’ online lives.

The Seattle Times had this comment on the article.

docs.snippet: During a very brief annual shareholder meeting on Tuesday, Microsoft's chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer, said: ''We are in an era where the range of smart devices is continuing to expand. That is a fantastic thing for Microsoft.''     So far, so...
docs.lead_paragraph: During a very brief annual shareholder meeting on Tuesday, Microsoft's chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer, said: ''We are in an era where the range of smart devices is continuing to expand. That is a fantastic thing for Microsoft.'' So far, so good. The explosion of smart devices, particularly phones and tablets, is notable. Almost all of them are devices running Apple's iOS and Google's Android software, though. Microsoft has its own mobile operating system in Windows Mobile, of course, and should get a boost next year from Windows 8 for phones and tablets. A seemingly careless statement to a French Web site by an executive at Nokia, Microsoft's close partner in phones, indicates that Nokia will have a Windows 8 tablet in June.

headline.main: Microsoft Office Missing for Tablets

docs.abstract: Bits blog notes Microsoft has few tablet apps; points out it will launch Windows 8 for phones and tablets in 2012. Photo (M)

docs.snippet: Facebook plans to create its own smartphone, Penguin will end digital library lending of new titles and Sarah Palin was nearly pulled from Fox News....
docs.lead_paragraph: Facebook has decided to create its own smartphone - code name Buffy, as in the vampire slayer - enlisting the Taiwanese company HTC to build it with the social network "integrated at the core of its being," according to report in AllThingsD, part of Dow Jones. (Neither Facebook nor HTC would confirm the report.) The phone will not make it to market for 12 to 18 months and is expected to use a modified version of the Android operating system created and released by Google, the Web site reported. While some online commentators questioned the wisdom of Facebook entering the hardware business from scratch, the AllThingsD account described the decision as about independence: "Google and Apple run the two major smartphone operating systems, giving Facebook little say over its mobile destiny."

docs.snippet: The best known services offering virtual phone numbers are Skype and Google Voice, but one service that's been gaining traction with small businesses is Toktumi....
docs.lead_paragraph: Four years ago, Andie Jones found herself overweight, out of shape and feeling generally unhealthy, thanks in large part to the demands of a high-powered career in marketing. After figuring out a new set of eating and exercise habits that got her health back on track, she started helping family, friends and colleagues do the same -- and got so much satisfaction out of it that two years ago she walked away from her job for a career reboot. After taking some certification courses, she put up a shingle for Be Well Nutrition, a nutrition and weight-loss coaching service specializing in helping time-strapped business executives and parents.

headline.main: One Way to Simplify Phone Chaos

docs.abstract: The best known services offering virtual phone numbers are Skype and Google Voice, but one service that's been gaining traction with small businesses is Toktumi.

docs.snippet: Web searches can help parents ensure that their child is not saddled with a negatively connoted name, but a unique, or uncommon one....
docs.lead_paragraph: What's new in the baby-naming game is the level of complexity that Google and other search engines have brought, reports Allen Salkin of The New York Times. He writes that some parents want names that are unique so their child will rise to the top of future search results. Others want names that are uncommon enough to bestow uniqueness, but not so exotic that they would be considered weird on the playground. A rare few want their child's name to get lost in a virtual crowd.

headline.main: What's in a Name? Ask Google

docs.abstract: Web searches can help parents ensure that their child is not saddled with a negatively connoted name, but a unique, or uncommon one.

docs.snippet: Earlier this week we published an article about Google Apps, and Google's struggle to displace Microsoft Office and Sharepoint inside large corporations. While Google has worked without a large consulting partner, it should be said that several sm...
docs.lead_paragraph: Earlier this week we published an article about Google Apps, and Google's struggle to displace Microsoft Office and Sharepoint inside large corporations. While Google has worked without a large consulting partner, it should be said that several smaller consultancies are working to encourage companies to adopt Google's cloud-based office productivity software. Among these are Dito, SADA Systems, Appirio and Cloud Sherpas. Each offers a somewhat different approach. SADA is reselling both Microsoft and Google products. Appirio offers Google along with a broad range of other cloud services for business, like Salesforce.com. Dito is making much of moving companies to Google's Chromebooks, which are lightweight laptops built for cloud interactions. Cloud Sherpas is among the largest consultants stressing Apps, and it claims to have moved over 1 million people to Google Apps.

headline.main: Small Consultants Work With Google

docs.abstract: Bits blog notes several small consultancies are working to encourage companies to adopt Google's cloud-based productivity software. (S)

docs.snippet: According to a new report to be issued Wednesday by Nielsen, the market research firm, Google and Apple are both winning in the mobile smartphone race. Android has become the operating system of choice for most consumers, partly because of the ine...
docs.lead_paragraph: It is not very often that you get two winners and two losers in the same competition. Yet according to a new report to be issued Wednesday by Nielsen, the market research firm, Google and Apple are both winning in the mobile smartphone race.

headline.main: Google and Apple Are Both Winners in Mobile Race, Report Says

docs.abstract: According to a new report to be issued Wednesday by Nielsen, the market research firm, Google and Apple are both winning in the mobile smartphone race. Android has become the operating system of choice for most consumers, partly because of the inexpensive handset options available through phone carriers. Apple's iPhone has become the predominant hardware choice, for 29 percent of all smartphone owners.

docs.snippet: While it is not quite as helpful as Apple's Siri personal assistant, Google has a voice-activated feature in its software that lets you search the Web by speaking search terms out loud....
docs.lead_paragraph: While it is not quite as helpful as Apple's Siri personal assistant, Google has a voice-activated feature in its software that lets you search the Web by speaking your search terms out loud. Google Voice Search is available in its mobile apps for the iPhone, BlackBerry and Nokia S60v3 mobile phones. Depending on which version of the software is installed on the phone, Android users have their own options, including the Google Search widget, the Voice Actions app for Android or other apps from the Android Market.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Using Google by Voice

docs.abstract: While it is not quite as helpful as Apple's Siri personal assistant, Google has a voice-activated feature in its software that lets you search the Web by speaking search terms out loud.

headline.main: Expect Some Toning Down of Antipiracy Bills, Says Movie Industry Supporter

docs.abstract: The changes to the legislation, which is meant to combat online piracy, are intended to answer some of the objections of Google, Yahoo and other technology companies, said Michael O'Leary of the Motion Picture Association of America.

docs.snippet: The changes to the legislation, which is meant to combat online piracy, are intended to answer some of the objections of Google, Yahoo and other technology companies, said Michael O'Leary of the Motion Picture Association of America....
docs.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES - Look for changes in the proposed antipiracy legislation that has giants in the entertainment and technology industries squared off against each other, but nothing extensive enough to please all of the legislation's opponents. That was the message from Michael O'Leary, the senior executive vice president for global policy and external affairs of the Motion Picture Association of America, during a telephone news briefing on Wednesday.

headline.main: Expect Some Toning Down of Antipiracy Bills, Says Movie Industry Supporter

docs.abstract: The changes to the legislation, which is meant to combat online piracy, are intended to answer some of the objections of Google, Yahoo and other technology companies, said Michael O'Leary of the Motion Picture Association of America.
